You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:

"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):

   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

Paper Title: Brain-Inspired Computational Intelligence via Predictive Coding

Paper Abstract: 

Paper Section Text:
The machine learning community is developing and producing models that push the boundaries of the field on a weekly basis. In the last year alone, we have witnessed considerable breakthroughs in the fields of generative artificial intelligence (AI) [ref]1 [ref]2  , game playing  , and text-generation   . These results reflect over a decade of advances in the field, made possible by the joint effort of tens of thousands of researchers and engineers who have built on the seminal work of Krizhevsky et al.Â on ImageNet  to improve the performance of deep artificial neural networks trained with the error backpropagation algorithm . Research and application domains that have been most significantly impacted include image recognition    , speech recognition , game playing   , and natural language understanding   . It may thus come as a surprise that research on alternative training methods for machine learning is more active than ever, with many works often co-authored by the same scientists who pioneered backpropagation-based schemes  [ref]22  . These lines of research, however, are not contradictory but complementary: the increasingly impressive results of standard deep neural networks have also highlighted several significant limitations. Alternative methods and approaches may play an enabling role in applications where the aforementioned limitations preclude further developments and advancements. Modern deep learning models are notoriously computationally expensive  , untrustable  , and biologically implausible  0  [ref]22 1 2 3 4. While identifying the steps that will allow us to solve these problems is difficult, a promising direction focuses on understanding, as well as reverse engineering, how the human brain learns generative models of the world 5  6. In this review, we argue that a fruitful approach to achieving the goal of efficient and intelligent machines lies within a theory of learning and perception in the brain, called predictive coding (PC) 7 8 9, which has its roots in Bayesian inference and signal compression. Notably, models of PC exhibit several intriguing and valuable properties. First, the locality of PC-based model inversion schemes allows the training of artificial neural networks with any given topology 2 0. This differs from backprop, which can only be applied to feedforward and acyclic models, unless derivatives over time are stored, resulting in an algorithm (i.e., backprop through time) that is as inefficient as it is biologically implausible. Locality is important, as it would facilitate the training of models with arbitrarily entangled structures, similar to the biological networks that constitute our brains and underwrite our level of intelligence 1. Furthermore, PC networks are naturally more robust in relation to standard models trained with backprop, due to the relaxation process that spreads error signals across the whole network. In supervised learning, this process emulates implicit gradient descent 2, is naturally more stable, and is less reliant on hyperparameter searches. This allows predictive-coding-based models to perform better in tasks that are more likely to be faced by natural agents, while regularizing the underlying energy landscape 3 and avoiding troublesome phenomena, such as vanishing and exploding gradients 4 5. Summarizing, PC has a solid mathematical formulation, with roots in signal compression and Bayesian inference 6.
